word.entryDescription: music, sound, or images that have been stored on tape or discs
word.entryExample: An orchestra in Japan started sending sick people recordings of classical music.

word.entryDescription: to become healthy again following an illness, accident, etc; to get better
word.entryExample: It will take him a long time to recover from that.

word.entryDescription: a computer file that you managed to get back after it got lost or deleted
word.entryExample: The problem with some recovered files is that sometimes not all your work is saved.

word.entryDescription: to get somebody new to work for a company, join an organisation, etc
word.entryExample: Red Arrow agency is recruiting a cleaner to work in a variety of city centre locations.

word.entryDescription: able to be recycled (of waste: treated in order to produce materials that can be used again)
word.entryExample: Many things are recyclable. There’s a full list on our website.

word.entryDescription: to use metal, paper, plastic and glass again
word.entryExample: We must recycle rubbish because it's good for the planet.

word.entryDescription: a facility which deals with segregating and processing materials for recycling
word.entryExample: If we bought a new TV we would take the old one to the recycling centre.

word.entryDescription: something that is red is the colour of blood (=the liquid inside your body)
word.entryExample: She's wearing a red T-shirt.

word.entryDescription: to make something smaller
word.entryExample: You need to reduce the amount of sugar that you eat.

word.entryDescription: a decrease in size, price, etc
word.entryExample: If you shopped in a supermarket, you'd get much better reductions.

word.entryDescription: an official in many sports who controls the game and makes sure the rules are being followed
word.entryExample: The referee is equipped with a whistle.

word.entryDescription: an image seen in a mirror, glass, or water
word.entryExample: Can you see our reflection in the water?

word.entryDescription: a type of alternative medicine in which particular regions of feet are pressed or rubbed to heal other parts of the body
word.entryExample: Reflexology is a foot massage based on a philosophy of energy channels similar to the Chinese meridian lines.

word.entryDescription: keeping food, etc. cold in order to keep it fresh or preserve it
word.entryExample: In the 19th Century, during the Industrial Revolution, there were a lot of developments in transport and refrigeration.

word.entryDescription: a piece of equipment used for keeping food at cool temperatures
word.entryExample: Our kitchen's got a refridgerator, freezer, cooker and microwave oven too but we've also got a dishwasher.

word.entryDescription: somebody who leaves their country or area to escape from conflict or because they are in danger due to their race, religion, beliefs, etc
word.entryExample: The homeless victims of wars and natural disasters end up in refugee camps.

word.entryDescription: to give back money to somebody after they have paid for something, usually because the have returned an item or are dissatisfied with a service
word.entryExample: If you're not satisfied, all you have to do is fill in a complaints form and we'll refund your money!

word.entryDescription: to say that you will not do or accept something
word.entryExample: He refused to admit that they had done anything wrong.

word.entryDescription: to feel sorry about something, especially something you did in the past
word.entryExample: People who run regularly often regret it in later life as they queue up for knee or hip replacements.

word.entryDescription: often, or repeatedly with the same amount of space or time between each event
word.entryExample: During the day, I regularly check the weather forecast to see if a storm is coming.

word.entryDescription: to decide not to accept, agree with or believe in somebody or something
word.entryExample: I'm sorry but your application has been rejected.

word.entryDescription: to rest or do something enjoyable, especially after doing something tiring
word.entryExample: I've just finished revising for the test and I'm relaxing a bit now.

word.entryDescription: way of resting or enjoying yourself
word.entryExample: People have practised relaxation techniques for thousands of years.

word.entryDescription: an act of passing something along from one person/group to another
word.entryExample: In the relay there were six teams.

word.entryDescription: a happy feeling caused by something unpleasant ending or not happening
word.entryExample: Two minutes later it was all over. The relief was incredible.

word.entryDescription: to continue to be in the same state or place; e.g. upright or stable
word.entryExample: A bike should remain upright when it is steered.

word.entryDescription: to keep or bring back information, an image, a feeling, etc in your mind
word.entryExample: I was walking to school when I remembered it was 'Teacher's Day'.

word.entryDescription: far away from cities and places where a lot of people live
word.entryExample: There are lots of trees in the background – it looks like it's in the country, somewhere quite remote.

word.entryDescription: a small object used to control an electronic device such as a television from a distance
word.entryExample: John wants the remote control, so that he can turn the TV on and check what's on.

word.entryDescription: to take something away from a place
word.entryExample: Enter your PIN and then choose or type the amount of cash you want. After this you can remove your card.

word.entryDescription: energy that is replaced naturally, by natural ecological cycles
word.entryExample: If we're going to reduce air pollution, we need to do research into renewable energy sources.

word.entryDescription: the money that you pay to rent something, particularly the regular payment for the use of someone's flat, building, land, etc
word.entryExample: She's pleased that the rent includes all the bills.

word.entryDescription: to pay to use something that belongs to someone else
word.entryExample: Jane and her young family have rented a large three double-bedroom family house.

word.entryDescription: to replace something that has been used
word.entryExample: Renewable energy sources replenish themselves quickly and can be used over and over again.

word.entryDescription: something that is said, written, or done as a way of replying
word.entryExample: Read Sally's reply to Brian's email and say what you think about it.

word.entryDescription: to say or write something in reaction to something somebody else has said or written
word.entryExample: Let's reply to Alma's invitation.

word.entryDescription: past form of 'report' – to tell the police or somebody in authority that something has happened
word.entryExample: He reported the theft to the police.

word.entryDescription: a person who reports news for a newspaper, on television, etc
word.entryExample: I'd like to be a reporter because you get to meet lots of people and tell their stories.

word.entryDescription: when you ask for something politely or formally
word.entryExample: Please put your request in writing.

word.entryDescription: to change the time at which something has been arranged
word.entryExample: Luckily, I rescheduled the meeting for later in the day and managed to get to my meeting – by train!

word.entryDescription: to save someone from a dangerous situation
word.entryExample: The army rescues people by boat.

word.entryDescription: detailed study of a particular subject in order to find out more about it or to test ideas
word.entryExample: Research showed that children who eat healthier meals can do better in tests.

word.entryDescription: somebody who does research
word.entryExample: Researchers use a simulator to find out how speed control affects the way people drive their cars.

word.entryDescription: to look like or be similar to somebody or something else
word.entryExample: This old game resembles our game of chess.

word.entryDescription: to ask for a car, table, room, etc. to be available for you or somebody else at a particular time in the future
word.entryExample: I'd like to reserve a boat for two hours tomorrow, please.

word.entryDescription: somebody who lives somewhere
word.entryExample: The flats are small but most of the residents have a balcony.

word.entryDescription: the place you come to for activity holidays
word.entryExample: The residential centre was in the middle of the Welsh countryside.

word.entryDescription: think about other people's feelings, wishes or rights
word.entryExample: It's important to respect other people's feelings.

word.entryDescription: something that it is your duty to do or be in charge of
word.entryExample: It's nothing to do with me – leaders and governments should take responsibility.

word.entryDescription: a period of time when you stop making an effort and relax for a while
word.entryExample: I'm not fit anymore this is why I have to have a rest after my grandchildren's visit.
